did.langmaterial: The material is in English; official material of the International Olympic Committee is in English and French; select material in other languages.
did.abstract: Douglas Fergusson Roby was a member of the International Olympic Committee from 1952-1985 and president of the United States Olympic Committee from 1965 to 1969. The collection includes materials related to his professional activities and interests and contains personal files, national and international Olympic and athletic organizations' files and photographs, as well as Roby's personal files and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Mrs. Hermine Klingler (donor no. 8114) in February, 1997 and March 2013.

accruals.p: No further additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Douglas F. Roby papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Douglas Fergusson Roby was born on March 24, 1898 in Port Tobacco, Maryland. In 1903 the family moved to Chicago, Ill. Roby attended Wendell Phillips High School in Chicago and the Michigan Military Academy in Brighton where he excelled at football and was recruited by Phillips University in Enid, Oklahoma in 1917. After attending Phillips, Roby transferred to the University of Michigan in February 1920, where he became a member of the Pi Delta Theta fraternity. In 1921 and 1922 he played on the university baseball team as a leftfielder and on the football team as a fullback. In 1923 he was inducted into Michigamua. Roby graduated from the University of Michigan with a degree in Business Administration in 1923.
After graduation, in 1923, Roby played football as a tailback for Cleveland Indians. He also played squash for the city of Detroit in 1928-1936, winning the national championship in 1932.

In 1934, he joined American Metal Products Company, an automobile parts supplier. Roby was elected president of the company in 1954, and retired as board chairman in 1963. In the course of his career he was on the board of other companies including, First Federal Savings and Loan of Detroit and Kelsey Hayes Wheel Company.

In addition to his business connections in Detroit, he was actively involved in the civic life of the city. Most notable are his efforts to bring the Olympics to Detroit. The city made several attempts, from 1944 to 1972, to get the games. Roby was prominent in each of these attempts. He also served as a member of the Detroit Arts Commission, a member of the Board of Directors of the Detroit Zoological Society and a trustee of Harper-Grace Hospitals.

Roby was very active in amateur athletic associations. From 1951 to 1953, he was elected president of the Amateur Athletic Union (AAU) of the United States. He served as president of the Pan Am Games from 1955 to 1960. Roby was vice president of the United States Olympic Committee (USOC) from 1953 to 1965 and served as its president from 1965 to 1968. At the 1952 Olympic Games, Roby was elected to the International Olympic Committee (IOC), to be one of two IOC American members. He resigned from IOC in 1985 and from USOC in 1986.

Roby was in the center of several controversies during his tenure as the U.S. Olympics official. During the 1968 Summer Olympics in Mexico City, as the USOC president, he ordered removal of Tommie Smith and John Carlos, two African-American athletes, from the U.S. Olympic team. The punishment came after Smith and Carlos raised black-gloved fists and bowed their heads while the national anthem of the United States was played during a medal ceremony. In 1979 Roby voted against the People's Republic of China's readmission to the Olympics (China was readmitted). In 1984 he unsuccessfully advocated for readmission of South Africa.
Roby died in April 1992 in Ann Arbor, Michigan.

scopecontent.p: This collection is divided into three series: Personal/Biographical, Olympic Games, and Photographs and photo albums. Personal/Biographical (1922-2003, 1 linear foot) series contains material concerning Roby's early life and business activities, as well as speeches, writings, and a scrapbook. The Olympic Games (1948-1988, 6 linear feet) series is the largest series in the collection and encompasses Roby's activities in various national and international sports associations. The Photographs and photo albums (1914-1989, 1.3 linear feet) series contains photographs from throughout Roby's life.

scopecontent.p: Found here is material related to his years at the University of Michigan and Phillips University in Enid, Oklahoma. He was prominent in the athletic programs of both schools as a student. Roby also took an active interest in the affairs of the schools as an alumnus. The bulk of the material related to his years as a student concerns his relationship with the University of Michigan.

A small selection of correspondence and clippings reflect on Roby's activities at American Metal Products in Detroit as well as his activities with Detroit based businesses First Federal Savings and Loan and Kelsey Hayes Wheel Company.

Speeches and articles are included as are publications which mention him prominently. Of particular note is a scrapbook containing clippings and photographs from 1950 to 1972. In 1987, Roby's daughter Hermine Roby Klingler complied The Personal History of Douglas Fergusson Roby, a collection of photographs and text about Roby's life. This volume is cataloged separately in the Bentley Historical Library's holdings (call no. DB 2 R668 A12).

The Personal/ Biographical series includes material related to Roby's civic activities for the city of Detroit: his tenure on the Detroit Arts Commission and activities in the Detroit Athletic Club (DAC). Also included material related to the honors and awards received by Roby, biographical information, newspaper clippings, and obituaries.

The Olympic Games series is the largest series in the collection and encompasses Roby's activities in various national and international sports associations, including the Amateur Athletic Association, the U.S. Olympic Committee, and the International Olympic Committee. This series also includes material related to individual Olympic Games and Pan American Games, Olympic bids --specifically, Detroit and Los Angeles,--and various issues that arose in preparation to and during Olympiads.
A large portion of the Amateur Athletic Association material is related to the AAU/NCAA controversy; also included general correspondence, clippings and publications.
The Detroit Olympic bids is a small collection of articles, clippings, and some correspondence related to the city's unsuccessful 1952-1972 Summer Olympics campaigns.

The International Olympic Committee is the largest part of the series. It include administrative files of the Committee: correspondence, minutes, reports and resolutions of general IOC Sessions, the Executive Board, and various IOC committees.

scopecontent.p: Subject files include Roby's correspondence with IOC presidents Avery Brundage, Michael Morris (Lord Killanin), and Juan Antonio Samaranch, as well as material on specific topics, such as China and South Africa's readmission to the Olympics, among others.

did.unittitle: People's Republic of China 1965-1981 with gaps

scopecontent.p: The Olympiads material includes correspondence and documentation related to Olympic bids, organization, and issues. For example, the 1968 Summer Olympic Games in Mexico material contains a "Smith and Carlos incident" folder; material related to the 1980 Moscow Summer Games includes discussion of the Games boycott by the United States. Also of significance is material related to organization of the 1980 Winter Olympic Games in Lake Placid and of the 1984 Summer Olympic Games in Los Angeles.
The Olympic Games Subject Files contain correspondence with individuals and on topics, such as Special Olympics and President's Commission on Olympic Sports, among others.

did.unittitle: U.S. Women's Basketball Team tour of South America 1970

scopecontent.p: The U.S. Olympic Committee material includes correspondence and meetings minutes, reports and resolutions.

The bulk of the material is personal photographs depicting Roby with friends and associates, high school and university class and sports team photos, as well as Roby's University of Michigan scrapbook. Also included photographs from sports associations of which he was a member and sporting events that he helped to plan. The series includes images of renowned athletes and sports figures, as well as political leaders, such as Jesse Owens, Fielding H. Yost, Franklin Cappon, Jim Ryun, George Romney, Prince Gholam Reza Pahlavi, among others. Also found here are photographs collected for use in The Personal History of Douglas Fergusson Roby. Of note is an undated outsize view of the Ohio State University stadium, autographed by Fielding H. Yost on the back side.
